stories.text:
Backstory: I've been running an uptime monitoring service for over a year now, and I realised much of the value comes from what happens after we detect downtime (alerts, incident response, and incident communication).

So I'm looking to integrate as many monitoring services as possible so folks can automate their team's incident response as well as communicating what's happening to their customers.

---

Hence the question: What does your team/employer use for uptime monitoring?
stories.title: Ask HN: What does your team use for uptime monitoring?
AWS EC2 vs. Azure Virtual Machine vs. GCP Compute Engine

stories.text:
I depend a lot on FLOSS for my work (and personal life) and I am doing my tiny bit to contribute and I am doing some financial donations too. Especially for the work part I'm more and more starting to feel it's my duty to help out financially, we've all seen too many stories of underfunded FLOSS projects not having the capacity to fix crucial bugs causing severe security problems, or projects throwing in the towel leaving downstream projects stranded. Most (all?) of the companies I've worked with in my career depend heavily (completely?) on FLOSS to do their heavy lifting. A typical business application build upon FLOSS covers less that 1‰ of the entire deployed code base so some compensation for those hard working maintainers and developers would seem helpful.

Doing ad hoc donations as I do now doesn't feel very constructive to me so I'm considering to do (automatically) reoccurring donations to my favorite organisations and tools, which doesn't seem fair to the stuff I do depend on but don't have warm feelings for, but I gotta start some where, right? What projects and organisations are you and/or the company you work for supporting? Any tips?
stories.title: Ask HN: Donating to FLOSS Projects?
